attributes.title: How important is election pledge fulfillment for voters’ evaluations of government performance? [Working title]

q1.value: How important is election pledge fulfillment for voters’ evaluations of government performance? [Working title]

q5.value: The author is grateful to LORE for providing the infrastructure for implementing this experiment, and in particular to Elina Lindgren for her crucial help in designing this experiment. , Many thanks are also due to my supervisors, Elin Naurin and Maria Oskarson, as well as to Peter Esaiasson for their invaluable input during various stages of this project. , Finally, the author wishes to express his gratitude to the department of Political Science, and the SOM Institute for making this research possible.

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: Classic contributions on representative democracy apportion an important role to election pledges. However, few studies have empirically examined how the fulfillment of election pledges affects voters, and in the literature on retrospective voting election pledge fulfillment is seldomly considered to be an important indicator of government performance – let alone an important determinant of vote choice. In this project, I will examine the relative importance of election pledge fulfillment to evaluations of government performance and party choice, in comparison to the most commonly used performance criteria: the economy and policy output. The study limits itself to retrospective components of vote choice, simultaneously estimating the contributions of the most commonly used indicators of government performance on evaluations of this performance. In essence, by comparing the congruence of implemented policy with personal and societal preferences on the one hand, and (policy neutral) pledge fulfillment on the other – the respondents are presented a choice between a form of mandate-representation (agent), and a more autonomous form of representation (trustee) where the government is more or less free to break their promises, as long as their decisions are supported, or the (economic) outcomes are good. The central question of the study is whether the extent to which a government party fulfilled its election pledges should take a more important role in the study of retrospective voting – as argued by classic works on representative democracy; or whether the retrospective voting literature has been correct in prioritizing economic development and policy action. Using a conjoint experiment with unlabelled former government parties, the relative importance of the most important indicators of government performance is estimated in isolation of disturbances found in the real world, but in confrontation with each other. Both evaluations of government performance and party choice are used as dependent variables. The results should have considerable implications for the study of representative democracy in general, and retrospective voting and election pledges in particular.

q16.value: How important do voters find it that government parties fulfill their election pledges; as compared to other indicators of government performance? Based on classic literature on representative democracy (e.g., Dahl, 1991; Downs, 1957) the extent to which government parties fulfill their election pledge should play an important role in how voters evaluate government performance, and their vote choice. In this study, this hypothesis is considered valid if the relative contribution of election pledge fulfillment to the probability of respondents choosing a party profile/or to the evaluation ratings of party profiles is equal to or exceeds that of any of the other included attributes. However, based on different strands of the retrospective voting literature other factors should be more important determinants of evaluations of government performance, and vote choice. According to the economic voting literature, it should be the state or development of the economy that is most important. Either on a societal level (sociotropic), or individual level (egotropic/pocketbook). Thus, an important competing hypothesis is that economic indicators are more important than pledge fulfillment as such. In this study, this hypothesis is considered valid if the relative contribution of both of the economic attributes to the probability of respondents choosing a party profile and to the evaluations rating of party profiles exceeds that of the election pledge fulfillment attribute. According to the wider retrospective voting literature, performance in other policy areas may be equally important (cf. Healy & Malhotra, 2013). Thus, another competing hypothesis is that the favorability of policy output – either on a societal level, or individual level, is deemed more important than pledge fulfillment as such. In this study, this hypothesis is considered valid if the relative contribution of both of the policy output attributes to the probability of respondents choosing a party profile and to the evaluations rating of party profiles exceeds that of the election pledge fulfillment attribute. I will also examine a potential interaction effect between election pledge fulfillment and individual favorability of policy output. It is to be expected that respondents view the fulfillment of pledges as positive when the produced policy is favored by them; but as negative when the policy is not favored by them (see Naurin et al., 2019).

q17.value: The experiment consists of a conjoint analysis of combined discrete-choice and ranking tasks that the respondents are confronted with. The basic setup is that respondents are asked to choose between two fictional, unlabelled political parties based on a set of five attributes with randomly assigned values. Each of these five attributes can take on three values – positive, neutral, or negative. In total, 243 unique party profiles are available – which puts the number of possible combinations of profiles at almost 30,000. As it would be completely unfeasible to have all possible pairs of profiles assessed by at least one respondent, a fractional factorial design was elected. To avoid primacy and ordering effects, the order of the attributes was randomized per respondent. Before the experiment commences, the respondents are shown a screen with a short introduction to the experiment, telling them about the study, what sort of task to expect, and what they should do. On the next screen, respondents are then shown two competing profiles (Party A and Party B) containing randomly-assigned values for these five attributes, per screen. They are then shown three questions that form the dependent variables of this study. First, the respondents are asked which of these two parties they would choose if they had to vote for either. Then, they are asked to evaluate each party’s time in office based on the descriptions provided, on a scale ranging from very bad (1) to very good (7). On the final screen, after the experiment is concluded, the respondents are asked how important they found each separate attribute. The data obtained from this experiment will be analyzed following the method set out by Hainmueller et al., (2014) for analyzing conjoint experiments in political science studies. All five attributes will be simultaneously regressed on the dependent variables, with the standard errors clustered at the respondent level. For the discrete choice data, the dependent variable is the estimated probability of choosing a party profile (0-1). For the ranking data, the dependent variable is the average rating of a party profile by the respondents (1-7). To avoid problems with degrees of freedom in the final models, the respondents are asked to complete only one task each – eliminating the need to cluster the standard errors at the respondent level. Attribute orthogonality is achieved by design in this study.

q23.value: LORE’s citizen panel as a whole has received ethics committee approval in Sweden. Individual studies are not typically subject to separate ethics evaluation.

q27.value: Laboratory of Opinion Research (LORE), University of Gothenburg

attributes.title: Sound the Alarm! Bias and Consequences in Cyber Risk

q1.value: Sound the Alarm! Bias and Consequences in Cyber Risk

q2.value: Miguel Alberto Gomez | Eula Bianca Villar

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: The study is intended to investigate the occurrence of cognitive biases in response to degradative cyber operations. Specifically, it investigates whether decision-makers ignore existing base-rates and thus inflate the actual level of threat both to and from cyberspace.

q16.value: The goal of the project is to investigate the psychological components associated with the inflation of threats from cyberspace. Specifically, the project demonstrates that analysis of decisions regarding events in cyberspace should not simply be focused on strategic or technological factors but should also include individual psychologies as key determinants. The outcome of this project can serve to assist policy makers in developing methodologies to better evaluate cyber threats. Furthermore, this contributes to a broadening of the nascent field of cyber security.

q17.value: The hypotheses will be tested using two between groups factorial vignette experiments (2x2 and 2x2x2) distributed online via the platform Prolific Academic. The hypotheses to be tested in this experiment are as follows: Hypothesis 1: Decision-makers ignore existing base-rates when faced with degradative cyber operations during disputes with other states. Hypothesis 2: Decision-makers are likely to privilege the last portion of information received. Hypothesis 3: Decision-makers are likely to ignore the existing base-rate to support information aligned with pre-existing images. Hypothesis 4: Decision-makers assigned with greater responsibilities are more likely to utilize information that results in immediate closure. Hypothesis 5: Decision-makers are likely to inflate base-rates in the direction of the preceding information, in a situation where events align with pre-existing images, and are assigned greater responsibility.

attributes.title: “Who are the ‘illegals’?: The Social Construction of Undocumented Status in the U.S.

q1.value: “Who are the ‘illegals’?: The Social Construction of Undocumented Status in the U.S.

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Lacking formal legal status has significant, negative consequences for immigrants in the U.S. (Massey and Gentsch 2014; Menjívar and Abrego 2012), as well as their (often U.S.-born) children (Bean, Brown and Bachmeier 2015). Nevertheless, “legality” is often an ambiguous state. Immigration laws are complex and even immigration authorities are often uncertain about immigrants’ statuses (Menjívar 2006). Given the uncertainty surrounding ‘illegality,’ how do immigration officers and the public identify individuals they believe to be ‘illegal’? We posit that people rely on social stereotypes to infer ‘illegality’. Building off work on the social construction of race (Omi and Winant 1994; Saperstein, Penner and Light 2013), gender (West and Zimmerman 1987), and other social categories (Berger and Luckmann 1966), we develop and test a theoretical model for the social construction of ‘illegality’. Prior research, which hints at the influence of social class and national origin in shaping perceived illegality, has consisted of qualitative studies of one or two communities. Understanding the attributes that shape public suspicions of illegality is important because individuals perceived to be illegal, regardless of their actual legal status, might experience negative repercussions. Managers or landlords may decide not to hire or rent to them out of fear of breaking the law or because they have strong negative feelings about illegality. Perceived illegality may also increase law enforcement scrutiny. In some jurisdictions, authorities have the power to stop individuals that they suspect of being undocumented (Flores 2017; Menjívar and Abrego 2012). Officers are not supposed to use race or national origin as indicators of undocumented status. Nevertheless, authorities’ own perceptions may be shaped by ethnic and class-based stereotypes, which could explain why low-income Latin Americans are disproportionately deported (Golash-Boza 2015). Perceived illegality may also help explain why Latinos receive lower call back rates from landlords than non-Hispanic whites or even Asians (Ghoshal and Gaddis 2015) or why they receive worse health care treatment (Asad and Claire 2017) and face more precarious working conditions than other ethnic groups (Ribas 2016). To understand the social construction of ‘illegality’ and understand its likely consequences, we ask: do individual attributes like national origin, social class, criminal record, and occupation shape perceived undocumented status in the U.S.? Further, what specific immigrant attributes would make it more likely that individuals would seek to report immigrants to government authorities?

q16.value: We will test whether perceived illegality varies by the following individual characteristics: national origin, occupation, education level, English proficiency, gender, age, years in the U.S., criminal record, and receipt of government benefits. These attributes were selected based on their importance in shaping natives’ perceptions of immigrants in general (Hainmueller and Hopkins 2015; Schachter 2016), as well as past qualitative research on suspicions of ‘illegality’ (Garcia 2014; Asad and Rosen 2017). Based on prior literature, we hypothesize that the following characteristics will increase the levels of perceived illegality among our respondents: Latin American national origin, low occupational status, low education level, male, young, few years in the U.S., with a criminal record, and recipient of government services. In addition, we will conduct two interaction tests. We expect that individuals committing violent crimes like sexual assault, burglary, and murder, along with stereotypical ‘immigrant’ crimes like identity theft and criminal gang affiliation, will be especially likely to be perceived as undocumented. In contrast, we expect that individuals with a history of white collar crime like insider trading and embezzlement will be less likely to be perceived as unauthorized. With regards to occupation, we hypothesize that status and formality will interact so that individuals in low status occupations in the informal economy will be especially likely to be perceived as illegal.

q17.value: To address these questions, we will use a paired conjoint survey experiment on a representative sample of 2,000 adult U.S. residents. This experiment will be applied by GfK. In the experiment, respondents will compare the profiles of two immigrants side by side that list a number of individual traits and decide whether they are undocumented or not. This allows us to test the independent effect of each dimension on perceived illegality net of all other attributes, as well as explore interactions among the attributes. The individual traits are: national origin, occupation, education level, English proficiency, gender, age, years in the U.S., criminal record, and receipt of government benefits. We use a survey experiment because it lets us compare the effects of multiple immigrant attributes on public perceptions (Schachter 2016). Our conjoint design (Hainmueller, Hopkins and Yamamoto 2014) allows us to create profiles of hypothetical immigrants who vary along several dimensions, including national origin, occupation, education level, English proficiency, gender, age, years in the U.S., criminal record, and receipt of government benefits. In the experiment respondents read a short passage which introduces the task by saying, “Identifying immigrants who are in the United States illegally is a government priority…” (see Design Appendix). They are then presented with two randomly assigned profiles and are asked, “Do you think these immigrants are illegal/undocumented? In other words, do you think they lack proper documentation status to be in the U.S.?” (Response Options: Yes, No). Respondents separately assess each immigrant profile. We use responses to this bivariate question as the dependent variable in our main analysis. To gain better leverage over how likely respondents are to act on their suspicions, all respondents are next asked, “Would you consider asking local law enforcement to investigate their immigration status?” (Response Options: Yes, No). We will test these hypotheses via simple difference in means tests.

attributes.title: Meditation and the capacity for empathy in the work place and society

q1.value: Meditation and the capacity for empathy in the work place and society

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: Meditation has been discussed as remedy to a series of health issues but also to instill a higher degree of mindfulness into those practicing it; it also is said to increase individuals ability for compassion and empathy (Birnie et al. 2010; Sedlmeier et al. 2012; Mascaro et al. 2012). This study elicits whether meditation affects individuals' capacity for empathy as in their ability to read emotions, exercised in their work-place (towards patients) as well as empathy targeted at others in the broader society (welfare recipients). We study employees of a large health care provider in Colchester, Essex. The project contains two parts (1) Three wave survey of all employees and collection of work performance indicators. (2) 6-month meditation instruction treatment of two sets of 20 employees (September 2017 - February 2018 and April 2018 to October 2018) The survey includes, among others, empathy measures that allow to estimate the influence of meditation activity. Various covariates -- demographics, work environment, psychological scales, political leanings -- will help to characterize the context in which the meditation treatment affects empathy.

q16.value: The study tests whether individuals ability to exercise empathy is increasing with meditation activity.

q17.value: The main effect of interest is the average treatment effect of receiving meditation instruction and meditating actively on subjects ability to show empathy. We make three comparisons: difference in empathy scales between pre-treatment and post-treatment wave (within subject), difference in average empathy between treatment groups 1 and 2 (between subject), and difference in average empathy between treatment (1 and 2) and control groups (between subject). We recruit a sample among all employees of Provide Colchester, a large health service provider located in Colchester, Essex, United Kingdom (Provide Colchester). The capacity for empathy is measured by the eye in mind test (ability to read emotions), by a compassion scale (empathy towards patients), and a scale tapping attitudes towards welfare recipients.

q27.value: Provide Colchester Human Resource department, Barry Spivack (meditation instructor)

attributes.title: Social Encouragement and Persuasion in a Union Recertification Election After Collective Bargaining Reform

q1.value: Social Encouragement and Persuasion in a Union Recertification Election After Collective Bargaining Reform

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Earlier this year, Iowa became the latest in a string of states to enact sharp cutbacks to the collective bargaining rights of its public workers. Two of the most important provisions include limiting the scope of bargaining of most public workers to wages and requiring public unions to win a majority of bargaining unit member votes in regular recertification elections (typically at the end of contracts). Other states, like Wisconsin, which have introduced similar reforms have seen sharp drops in public union memberships, budgets, and political engagement. Through a partnership with the Iowa State Education Association (ISEA), the state's union representing public school teachers and staff, we will examine what kind of messages best persuade union members to turn out to vote in recertification elections. Specifically, we will be investigating what effects framing the union as a provider of collective benefits, professional benefits or insurance/job protection benefits has on turnout in the recertification election. We will also be examining whether these frames are more or less effective when interacted with social proof conditions. While past work has examined union members' attitudes towards unions, that work has generally been in the context of private sector unions in past decades, when the labor movement was much larger and stronger. Our current study is significant in that it focuses on the public sector and does so in a context of unfavorable state public policy, an increasingly common occurrence. Our results will speak to the motivations that public sector workers have to continue supporting unions in the context of punitive labor law, as well as the broader processes of persuasion and mobilization in contemporary labor organizations.

q16.value: On October 10th, 2017, the Iowa Educational Association (ISEA) will mail its approximately 10,542 voting members messages we have designed in partnership with them about the upcoming recertification election. At the end of every message will be a link to a website where members can vote for recertification electronically. We posit the following hypotheses: Hypothesis 1: Members who receive a message emphasizing that the union provides them a collective voice in their school, school district, and the state legislature will be more likely to vote in a union recertification election, compared to control. Hypothesis 2: Members who receive a message emphasizing that the union provides them professional benefits, like continuing education requirements and certification, will be more likely to vote in a union recertification election, compared to control. Hypothesis 3: Members who receive a message emphasizing that the union provides them with insurance and legal protections against job-related litigation will be more likely to vote in a union recertification election, compared to control. Hypothesis 4: Members who receive a message emphasizing either the collective voice, professional benefits, or insurance protections that the union provides, when the message also contains testimony from a fellow union member attesting to those benefits (amounting to social proof) will be more likely to vote in a union recertification election, compared to members who received those same messages without such testimony. Hypothesis 5: Members who receive a message emphasizing either the collective voice, professional benefits or insurance that the union provides, when the message also contains testimony from a fellow union member attesting to those benefits (amounting to social proof) and when the testimony is described as coming from a similar local as their own, will be more likely to vote in a union recertification election, compared to members who received those messages without such testimony, and compared to members who received such testimony that was not identified as coming from a similar local as their own.

q17.value: To test these hypotheses, we will randomly assign subjects to see one of the following ten messages: A message that emphasizes professional benefits provided by ISEA A message that emphasizes the collective voice provided by ISEA A message that emphasizes the insurance and legal protections provided by ISEA A message that emphasizes professional benefits provided by ISEA, combined with testimony from union members attesting to this benefit A message that emphasizes the collective voice provided by ISEA, combined with testimony from union members attesting to this benefit A message that emphasizes the insurance and legal protections provided by ISEA, combined with testimony from union members attesting to this benefit A message that emphasizes professional benefits provided by ISEA, combined with testimony from union members attesting to this benefit, and identified as coming from member of a similar local as the subject A message that emphasizes the collective voice provided by ISEA, combined with testimony from union members attesting to this benefit, and identified as coming from member of a similar local as the subject A message that emphasizes the insurance and legal protections provided by ISEA, combined with testimony from union members attesting to this benefit, and identified as coming from member of a similar local as the subject A control message consisting of standard ISEA messaging To evaluate our hypotheses, we will first regress voter turnout on indicator variables for all treatment conditions, excluding the control condition, with standard errors clustered at the local level. We will do this with and without any covariate data on members that ISEA provides us. Hypotheses 1-3 will be tested on this basis. To further test these hypotheses, we will create an indicator variable for messages 1, 4 and 7; another indicator variable for messages 2, 5 and 8; and another for messages 3, 6 and 9. We will then regress this against control, again with and without covariates, and again with standard errors clustered at the local level. To test Hypothesis 4, we will evaluate the difference between messages 1 and 4, messages 2 and 5, and messages 3 and 6. To further test Hypothesis 4, we will create an indicator variable for all those who saw messages 1-3 and one for those who saw messages 4-6, and evaluate the difference. To test Hypothesis 5, we will compare messages 4 and 7, 5 and 8, and 6 and 9. To further test Hypothesis 5, we will create an indicator variable for all those who saw messages 4-6 and one for those who saw messages 7-9, and evaluate the difference. All tests will be two-tailed. We will measure voter turnout in two ways. First, we will evaluate click-through data. If a recipient clicks on the link to vote, we will count them as having demonstrated a willingness to vote. Second, to the extent possible under Iowa state labor law, we will match the voting records of members with their treatment assignment.

q27.value: The ISEA will deliver the messages and the data to the researchers.

registration_responses.q1: Social Encouragement and Persuasion in a Union Recertification Election After Collective Bargaining Reform
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to assignment of treatment
registration_responses.q15: Earlier this year, Iowa became the latest in a string of states to enact sharp cutbacks to the collective bargaining rights of its public workers. Two of the most important provisions include limiting the scope of bargaining of most public workers to wages and requiring public unions to win a majority of bargaining unit member votes in regular recertification elections (typically at the end of contracts). Other states, like Wisconsin, which have introduced similar reforms have seen sharp drops in public union memberships, budgets, and political engagement. Through a partnership with the Iowa State Education Association (ISEA), the state's union representing public school teachers and staff, we will examine what kind of messages best persuade union members to turn out to vote in recertification elections. Specifically, we will be investigating what effects framing the union as a provider of collective benefits, professional benefits or insurance/job protection benefits has on turnout in the recertification election. We will also be examining whether these frames are more or less effective when interacted with social proof conditions. While past work has examined union members' attitudes towards unions, that work has generally been in the context of private sector unions in past decades, when the labor movement was much larger and stronger. Our current study is significant in that it focuses on the public sector and does so in a context of unfavorable state public policy, an increasingly common occurrence. Our results will speak to the motivations that public sector workers have to continue supporting unions in the context of punitive labor law, as well as the broader processes of persuasion and mobilization in contemporary labor organizations.
registration_responses.q16: On October 10th, 2017, the Iowa Educational Association (ISEA) will mail its approximately 10,542 voting members messages we have designed in partnership with them about the upcoming recertification election. At the end of every message will be a link to a website where members can vote for recertification electronically. We posit the following hypotheses: Hypothesis 1: Members who receive a message emphasizing that the union provides them a collective voice in their school, school district, and the state legislature will be more likely to vote in a union recertification election, compared to control. Hypothesis 2: Members who receive a message emphasizing that the union provides them professional benefits, like continuing education requirements and certification, will be more likely to vote in a union recertification election, compared to control. Hypothesis 3: Members who receive a message emphasizing that the union provides them with insurance and legal protections against job-related litigation will be more likely to vote in a union recertification election, compared to control. Hypothesis 4: Members who receive a message emphasizing either the collective voice, professional benefits, or insurance protections that the union provides, when the message also contains testimony from a fellow union member attesting to those benefits (amounting to social proof) will be more likely to vote in a union recertification election, compared to members who received those same messages without such testimony. Hypothesis 5: Members who receive a message emphasizing either the collective voice, professional benefits or insurance that the union provides, when the message also contains testimony from a fellow union member attesting to those benefits (amounting to social proof) and when the testimony is described as coming from a similar local as their own, will be more likely to vote in a union recertification election, compared to members who received those messages without such testimony, and compared to members who received such testimony that was not identified as coming from a similar local as their own.
registration_responses.q17: To test these hypotheses, we will randomly assign subjects to see one of the following ten messages: A message that emphasizes professional benefits provided by ISEA A message that emphasizes the collective voice provided by ISEA A message that emphasizes the insurance and legal protections provided by ISEA A message that emphasizes professional benefits provided by ISEA, combined with testimony from union members attesting to this benefit A message that emphasizes the collective voice provided by ISEA, combined with testimony from union members attesting to this benefit A message that emphasizes the insurance and legal protections provided by ISEA, combined with testimony from union members attesting to this benefit A message that emphasizes professional benefits provided by ISEA, combined with testimony from union members attesting to this benefit, and identified as coming from member of a similar local as the subject A message that emphasizes the collective voice provided by ISEA, combined with testimony from union members attesting to this benefit, and identified as coming from member of a similar local as the subject A message that emphasizes the insurance and legal protections provided by ISEA, combined with testimony from union members attesting to this benefit, and identified as coming from member of a similar local as the subject A control message consisting of standard ISEA messaging To evaluate our hypotheses, we will first regress voter turnout on indicator variables for all treatment conditions, excluding the control condition, with standard errors clustered at the local level. We will do this with and without any covariate data on members that ISEA provides us. Hypotheses 1-3 will be tested on this basis. To further test these hypotheses, we will create an indicator variable for messages 1, 4 and 7; another indicator variable for messages 2, 5 and 8; and another for messages 3, 6 and 9. We will then regress this against control, again with and without covariates, and again with standard errors clustered at the local level. To test Hypothesis 4, we will evaluate the difference between messages 1 and 4, messages 2 and 5, and messages 3 and 6. To further test Hypothesis 4, we will create an indicator variable for all those who saw messages 1-3 and one for those who saw messages 4-6, and evaluate the difference. To test Hypothesis 5, we will compare messages 4 and 7, 5 and 8, and 6 and 9. To further test Hypothesis 5, we will create an indicator variable for all those who saw messages 4-6 and one for those who saw messages 7-9, and evaluate the difference. All tests will be two-tailed. We will measure voter turnout in two ways. First, we will evaluate click-through data. If a recipient clicks on the link to vote, we will count them as having demonstrated a willingness to vote. Second, to the extent possible under Iowa state labor law, we will match the voting records of members with their treatment assignment.

attributes.title: Enabling Local Fiscal Capacity through Business Formalization

q1.value: Enabling Local Fiscal Capacity through Business Formalization

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Micro and small enterprises account for a large share of employment in Colombia. In an effort to both strengthen these businesses and increase their fiscal contribution, recent policy efforts have simplified the formalization process and reduced renewal fees. Unfortunately, many businesses remain uninformed about the process, these policy changes, and the benefits to formalizing. We evaluate whether direct outreach to micro and small enterprises increases formalization rates in Soacha, Colombia. We also pair this outreach with additional support that helps businesses realize the benefits of formalizing.

q16.value: We plan to test the following hypotheses, which map to our primary outcome families, specified in the appendices of the PAP (e.g., Formalization, Extortion, Tax Compliance): H1. Treatment increases formalization. H2. Treatment increases the perceived benefit-cost of formalization H3. Formalization reduces extortion. H4. Formalization increases tax compliance. H5. Formalization increases tax enforcement. H6. Formalization increases business performance. H7. Formalization increases business investment. H8. Formalization increases adoption of professional business practices. H9. Formalization increases increases banking. H10. Formalization increases credit access.

q17.value: For (H1)-(H2), we test whether both of the treatments jointly increase formalization rates relative to control. While we estimate the ITT for (H3)-(H10), we are primarily interested in the LATE, which is the effect among those that comply and formalize when approached. As part of Metaketa II, we also construct families for testing the hypotheses that will be the subject of the meta-analysis.

attributes.title: Multi-paper study (TGCC IE): The Impact of Customary Land Certification on Land Tenure and Resource Governance: Results of the Tenure and Global Climate Change RCT in Zambia

q1.value: Multi-paper study (TGCC IE): The Impact of Customary Land Certification on Land Tenure and Resource Governance: Results of the Tenure and Global Climate Change RCT in Zambia

q2.value: Heather Huntington | Aleta Haflett Starosta | Ben Ewing

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: The USAID Tenure and Global Climate Change (TGCC) Zambia Climate Smart Agriculture (CSA) pilot is a 2.5-year intervention designed to increase tenure security while also supporting agroforestry extension services. The TGCC pilot is being implemented in Chipata District, one of eight districts of Zambia’s Eastern Province, from late summer 2014 through the end of 2016. TGCC is a global program created by USAID to explore the relationship between secure resource tenure and the achievement of climate change adaptation and mitigation goals. In Zambia, TGCC will support activities that increase tenure security at the chiefdom, village, and household levels, while also supporting agroforestry extension services, primarily at the village level. The work also addresses USAID/Zambia’s objectives of improving governance, reducing rural poverty through increased smallholder agriculture productivity, improving natural resource management, and improving the resilience of vulnerable households. The TGCC interventions that comprise the impact evaluation’s (IE’s) focus are: Agroforestry extension in villages to facilitate tree planting adoption and survivorship on smallholder farms; and A village-level land tenure intervention consisting of participatory mapping, village headperson land administration support, provision of land information and dispute resolution training, including the facilitation of customary land use certificates for households. The primary objective of the IE is to determine whether the village and household land tenure interventions under TGCC strengthen the security of land tenure and resource rights for smallholders, thereby increasing farmer investment in sustainable agroforestry and uptake of other CSA practices. The overarching policy question of interest is: “How do changes in property rights that strengthen a farmer’s perception of long term security over farmland affect a farmer’s decision to practice climate smart agriculture, including agroforestry, on their own farms?” The evaluation breaks this into two key research questions for hypothesis testing. First, does the intervention strengthen farmer's perception of tenure security? And assuming it does, does it make the farmer more willing to adopt climate-smart agriculture.

q16.value: H: Villages receiving the land tenure intervention have different levels of village-wide incidence of land conflicts. H: Households in villages receiving the land tenure intervention perceive different levels of tenure security. H: Villages receiving the land tenure intervention perceive different levels of transparency regarding the land allocation process and accountability of land allocation decision makers. H: Households in villages receiving the land tenure intervention have different levels of satisfaction regarding the resolution of land disputes. H: Villages receiving the agroforestry intervention have different agroforestry and CSA uptake rates and planting survivorship. H: Households in villages receiving the agroforestry intervention adopt agroforestry practices and engage in agroforestry and related CSA activities at a different rate H: Households in villages receiving the land-tenure intervention have different livelihood outcomes, including the adoption of soil conservation farming practices.

q17.value: The study utilizes a factorial design to test the impacts of each component of the program, in addition to the marginal impact of strengthening land tenure on agroforestry and investment outcomes. To assess the individual and joint effect of each of the tenure and agroforestry interventions, the evaluation design is a four-arm village-level RCT. The IE is comprised of four treatment arms, consisting of the different interventions or combination of interventions that treatment villages received (agroforestry extension, tenure-security strengthening activities, or both). Villages were randomized into these four treatments across four chiefdoms: Mnukwa, Mkanda, Mshawa, and Maguya. A comparison of findings in agroforestry villages versus control and land tenure versus control provides the average program impact on each of these components. The comparison of the average outcomes in the group receiving both program components provides evidence about the additional effect of land tenure certification in promoting investment and CSA.

q24.value: Baseline: ERES: Number 2014-Apr-010, Clark: Number 2013-118; Endline: ERES: Number 2017-May-050, Clark: Number 2013-118

q25.value: Baseline: ERES: Number 2014-Apr-010, approved June 10, 2014 Clark: Number 2013-118, approved May 2014; Endline: ERES: Number 2017-May-050, approval received June 21st, 2017 Clark: Number 2013-118, approved May 3, 2017

attributes.title: Socialisation, Trajectories and Political Careers of Women in Chile

q1.value: Socialisation, Trajectories and Political Careers of Women in Chile

q5.value: We are grateful to CONICYT/FONDECYT/1100877 for providing access to the Chilean Elite Survey (1990-2010).

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Gender inequality is a condition that a affects woman in all walks of life. In representative democracies, the gap between men and women is tied to the political equality concept, one of the substantive principles of the democratic system. Egalitarian political participation is expressed on two interdependent levels, on which contemporary representation is also based. First, on the level of the governed, political equality is tied to effective participation in the decisions of a country. On the other hand, on the level of the ruling class, political equality is expressed in the egalitarian access to power and in influence, in other words, the chance to occupy positions of political representation or to have an influence or exert pressure (Dahl, 1971, 2007).

q16.value: H1. Men have greater probability of developing outstanding political careers in Chile from 1990 to 2010. H2. Outstanding political activism allows outstanding political careers of women in Chile from 1990 to 2010. H3. Outstanding technical resources allows outstanding political careers of women in Chile from 1999 to 2010. H4. Political family capital allows outstanding political careers of women in Chile from 1990 to 2010.

q17.value: We use mixed methods, specifically the triangulation framework (see Jick, 1979; Tarrow, 1995). First, we fit large-N econometric models (N = 386). We use GLM applied to different schemes of variables (binary and quasi-quantitative). With these models we test H1, which is related with the existence of a gender bias in political careers. We use the binary variable sex, which takes a positive value for men, thereby a statistically significant positive relation in the models is associate to a gender bias in political careers. Subsequently, we apply a medium-N QCA in the subset of women (n = 64). This allows us to test the causal condition of H2, H3, and H4, as well as to carry out three procedures: (i) elaborate a typological theorising to analyse career patterns with tree diagrams; (ii) carry out an analysis of the necessary and sufficient conditions with crisp-set QCA (csQCA) and fuzzy-set QCA (fsQCA) among the conditions and the development of outstanding political careers (y); and (iii) apply the Quine-McCluskey algorithm (QMC) to obtain a configurational model.

q19.value: A sample of 386 observations and a subsample of 64 women.
